It all took cash, and I didn’t have the guts anymore. But I could make it seem like I did.
Typing fast, keying in the serial number from a pink slip Glancing around nervously.
Beth had fifteen outstanding accounts, so I found fifteen replacement parts. I actually got the computer to buy my story. My foolproof plan, put into action.
Remy sneaks by a sleeping GUARD, then turns --
Except for the part about not getting caught. Jake is there. He’s seen everything.
Hey.
Hey. They stare at each other; neither knows what to say. Jake leans against the Credit Union sphere-and-bolt statue. Wh it finally begins, their conversation is as casual as eve
My uncle was a bank robber. I ever tell you that?
Uncle Joe?
Nah, my mom's brother, Lou. Made a whole mess of the West Coast, knockin’ over savings and loans.
No shit.

And the man was good at it -- nobody knew a damn thing. Most days, he woke up and went to work at the auto shop, but every so often he’d skip out for lunch and pull on a ski mask. Fifteen years he did this. And then one day, he forgot to wear gloves, and they pulled a print from some bullshit drunk and disorderly twenty years back. A day later, the cops were knocking on his door.
Lemme guess -- he was relieved.
No, he was fucking pissed. (beat; softer) But he just wasn’t that guy anymore. He was off his game, and he knew it.
Maybe it was a blessing.
Maybe. They stare at each other, understanding each other perfectly.
What am I supposed to do for money? I can’t do anything else.
It’d be the same for me.
Then what?
You find a way. Talk to Frank about the sales thing. Make Carol happy.  56.
And if I suck at it?
Do something else. But you gotta keep those payments coming. Soon as you fall behind, that’s Day One.
And six months later...
We put a guy on you. Remy stares off, the reality hitting him hard. He sees Raymond Pearl walking off with a fresh pink sheet.
Probably Ray.
Or me. Job’s a job.
Job’s a job. Remy turns to leave. His fate is set. Then turns back --
Where is he now?
Who?
Uncle Lou.
You know that erotic cake shop up on eighth street? That’s his.
Is he happy?
He makes pornographic desserts for a living. You tell me. Jake and Remy share one last grin.
Remy shuffles away from the mall, only a few parking lot halogens lighting his lonely path.
Remy sits across from a beleaguered looking Frank.
Frank surprised me. He took it better than I expected. Frank erases Remy’s name from the big board. Then -- thro the eraser at the wall in anger. He’s lost his best guy.
Remy, looking uncomfortable in suit and tie, sits across from a family of four in a sales booth.

Mr. Timmons, you owe it to your family. You owe it to yourself. The sickly looking patriarch nods and takes the pen. But before he signs, Remy continues... REMY (CONT’D) ‘Course, if you can’t pay your bills, some Union guy like me might show up next to your bed, wake you out of a sound sleep and run a scalpel from your collar bone down to your pelvis to reclaim our property. (beat) I’m just saying. The man drops the pen. His wife faints.
I wasn’t cut out for sales.
Remy raises a cleaver high into the air. His apron is covered in blood.

But I had to work. So I tried something a little more in line with my training. Remy slams the cleaver down onto a butcher block -- separating a sirloin steak. Remy’s trying his hand behind the deli counter. He whacks at a slab of meat, over and over again, juices flying --
back away from the counter, horrified.
Six months, and I must have tried twenty different jobs.

Remy, in an embarrassing T.G.I.Friday’s type ensemble delivers several meals to a table full of college guys. O particularly assholish frat guy waves Remy over, lifts hi hamburger bun to show that his food is not cooked right.

The customer, they say, is always right. I’d never really thought about what that meant before. Remy takes the basket of food and jams it into the guy’s face, knocking him over in his chair -- And then wailing on him while the stunned frat boys look on.
Remy and Beth pack up. Clothes. Work gear. He gently pack away his scalpels, ether cannisters... Looks at them fond
It’s amazing how fast a hundred and eighty days can go by. Beth puts a hand on Remy’s arm.
If you go with me, you’re done.
I’m done anyway.

Crappy street. Crappy neighborhood. Remy and Beth, their bags at their feet, stand outside Remy’s car. Remy pulls out a glass bottle filled with gas, a soaked r in the neck. He lights the rag with a match -- And tosses the bottle into the front seat of his car. He and Beth walk away, bags in hand, as the fire engulfs the car, erasing any trace of its existence.

Remy and Beth keep their heads low as they stick to the shadows along a trash-strewn sidewalk. As they head toward the entrance of this sad excuse for a building, we realize it’s the same burned-out hotel on th same ugly abandoned road where we first met Remy.
Welcome to paradise.
Remy and Beth scope out the rooms, trying to find a suitable place to hide out.
There are hiders, and there are seekers.
Beth takes the reins, showing Remy how and where to board up the windows, doors, setting booby traps, etc.
Hiding was new to me. But Beth had practice. She reaches over and turns off Remy’s flashlight.
Rule number one: Natural light only.
As Beth and Remy root through a dumpster. Remy holds up t pieces of fabric, one blue, one red. Beth points to the red.
And they hang the red fabric over the window.
Curtains!
Remy RIPS open a hole in the wall with a hammer and fluff pink insulation pops out. Beth grabs a handful and shoves it into a pillowcase, and Remy does likewise.

The decorations are complete, a woman's touch amid the debris. Candles, a blue tarp for a tablecloth, a stolen mattress for a bed. Flowers poke out of cracks in the wal Remy lays out weapons: Taser, scalpel, shotgun...

Remy searches through piles of broken furniture, testing busted chair legs and posts for use as potential weapons. As he swings a piece of wood through the air, he notices something beneath a pile. He clears away trash to find:
An old typewriter. He grabs it, blows off the dust. Tests the weight, as if to use it to crush in someone’s head, b then gets another idea... The faint CLACK of a typewriter sends us:
RACING through the dilapidated lobby, up the stairs, and into...
Where Remy sits at the typewriter, naked, back where we m him at the very beginning. We’re now where we first came in.

But you can only hide for so long before they find you. Suddenly, LAUGHTER. Remy, spooked, leaps to his feet. Shotgun in one hand, pistol suddenly in the other. Laughter again. Distinct. High-pitched. Remy tenses --
Remy, shotgun in hand, follows the laughter. Coming from down the hall --

Louder now, interspersed with voices. Remy presses himsel against the wall, breathing hard. Shotgun out the window Children. THREE LITTLE GIRLS, playing in the courtyard below. Remy relaxes as the girls pull out a jump-rope and begin chanting a song to count out their game:

There was a man from Troubadour/ Who got blown up during The War/ He did not die, would not concede/ How many artiforgs did he need? Stomach! Bladder! Pancreas! Eyes! Intestine! Heart! Kidney! Liver... Remy shakes his head at his own paranoia --

If you're going to shoot the kids, aim for the big one. More meat on her.  61. Remy lowers the shotgun barrel and turns to find Beth. Sh tosses his clothes at him. Remy begins to dress as Beth walks over by the typewriter.
For a guy who’s so paranoid, you sure make a lot of noise.
The writing helps me think.
What is it? A book? Epic poem?
It’s a letter.
To who?
Peter. My son.
I never played you for a dad.
Neither did I. Beth moves forward, then stops -- alarmed --
Somebody’s coming.
What?
You don’t hear it? Beth and Remy peek out the window, peering down to the street.
All I hear are those damn kids.
The girls are still jumping rope, now singing...
Tell it to the Mama/ Tell it to the son/ They all be gone when the day is done/ On come the wrinkles/ On come the sneeze/ The old man dies on his old man knees...
Beth grabs Remy’s ear lobe, twisting. He yelps.
Still natural? I can’t believe you haven't upgraded these. Beth digs through a nearby crate and fishes out a long, thin wire. Tiny pad on one end, a metallic jack on the other.
Put this in your ear. Remy looks down at the tiny pad, watching as Beth inserts the metallic jack into her ear cavity. It digs in tight, finally CLICKING into place.
Vocom makes share wires?

It’s aftermarket. Shut up and listen. Remy puts the “earphone” into his ear to share Beth’s amplified hearing. Suddenly, bis world comes alive with sound. Past the girl singing. Past the traffic. Finding a BARKING dog in the distance. An arguing couple, ignoring the quiet CRIES of the baby in the next room.

(incredibly loud) What am I -- Remy and Beth both cringe at his overly amplified voice. Beth scolds him with her eyes, showing him the small whee controls in the skin behind her ear that she continues to amplify, screening out the ambience. Focusing. Wings flapping. Footsteps. And finally, the familiar PING! PING! of an official Union-issue scanner. Remy yanks the wire out of both of their ears. REMY (CONT’D) Get away from the window.
Raymond Pearl reaches into his duffel, extracting a taser a scalpel, and an enormous gun. Clearly not Union issue.
Who is that?  63.
Ray Pearl. Psychopath with a Union scalpel.
(grabs Remy’s gun) I’ve got something for him.
He’s not here for you.
Gun in hand, Raymond strides right past the jump rope girls. They continue their chant, the rhythm growing faster...
Tension mounting as Remy and Beth run short on time.
There’s the back fire escape --
No. I have something better. Follow me. As Beth follows Remy towards the hall...
Raymond’s boots kick up dust as he mounts the stairs, his scanner honing in. PING - PING - PING -
On the jump rope girls’ feet, skipping impossibly fast.
The old man dies on his old man knees!
Raymond kicks a door off its remaining hinge. The room is charred out. A blue tarp sits on the otherwise rotted floor. Remy sits on the far side of the room, typing.
Pathetic. I can’t believe you were a Level Five. Remy looks up. Mock surprise.
They sent the ear guy after me? That hurts.
You're a funny guy. I’11 laugh at that when I got your heart in my hand.
(seductively) Ooh. Come here, sweet talker.
It’s gonna be a pleasure rippin’ off that tattoo. Remy stands for a fight. Raymond bull rushes. And just as he trounces across the middle of the blue tarp...

head_text.subj: THE BURNED OUT FLOOR GIVES WAY

text: Wood splintering, cracking -- Raymond plunging downward. Remy looks up at Beth, who was hiding behind the door. Th share a smile... UNTIL THE REST OF THE FLOOR CONTINUES TO CRUMBLE. Beth backs up against the wall -- the floor cracking towards her -- Remy leaping -- but she’s swallowed up -- Remy watches in horror as Beth plunges two stories down, loud CRACK as she hits the floor near Raymond. Remy bolts

Beth lays amid a ton of debris, barely conscious, clutchi her badly twisted knee. She spots Remy’s gun on the floor nearby. Reaches -- straining -- Raymond drags himself along the floor, battered and bloodied, but still moving forward. He grabs the gun, looks up --
You'll do. A sick smile crosses his lips -- he pulls the trigger --
Stomps Raymond’s hand back down, pinning the gun to the floor. The SHOT goes wild. Raymond looks up to see Remy standing over him, pumping t sawed-off shotgun...
A terrifying BLAST freaks out the jump rope girls. As the sprint off, leaving their jump rope behind... .
Remy carries an unconscious Beth toward their room. She emits a small groan, eyelids fluttering.
(soft, almost tender) Hey, there. You’re back with us. Beth’s hand rifles upward, clamping hard around Remy’s throat. They both fall to the floor.
(choking) Beth -- it’s me -- Beth’s eyes flutter open. She realizes it’s Remy and quickly releases him. Remy coughs -- REMY (CONT’D) Jesus Christ --
Sorry. You live on the streets long enough... She brushes herself off and tries to stand -- Nearly falling again. Her artiforg knee is a mess.
Let me carry you.
I’ve got it. Beth tries to take a few more steps, but limps horribly.

Come on, you’re leaking hydraulic fluid all over. BETH . I can fix it myself. She sits on the floor and tears open her pants, exposing her open wound. Her metallic kneecap glints in the moonlight, the artiforg metal puncturing her natural fles Reaching into her bra, Beth pulls out a small package of tools -- screwdriver, hammer, miniature soldering iron. S fiddles with the artiforg, wincing from the pain.
(staring at her knee) You know how quick I could pluck that Dura-joint right outta your leg?
(grunting through pain) Wouldn't -- really -- help us.
Under 12 seconds. Beth stops what she’s doing and looks at Remy, then twist away at something metal in her leg. It CLICKS.
I think I got it. Help me up. Remy pulls Beth to her feet. Her limp’s not so bad now, b she’s clearly in pain. BETH (CONT’D) It‘ll hold.
We can’t rest, we have to go. They found me faster than I thought.
You think there’11l be more of them?
Once they’re on you, they don’t stop.
So what do we do?
The Mall, as usual, is abuzz with activity. Remy slinks down a side street and into an alley.
Larry The Lung steps out into the alley and, with a grunt removes the top half of his costume. He’s just a teenager The half-dressed lung pulls out a cigarette and lights up
Hell of an example you're setting.
‘Hey, pal, I’m on a break -- Remy steps out, and Larry’s eyes go wide -- LARRY THE LUNG (CONT’D) Sir, I didn’t -- I mean --
I got a thirty-four waist. You?
Th -- Thirty.
Fucking metabolism... A swift ELBOW to Larry’s head, and the kid CRASHES to the ground. Remy stomps out the cigarette still in Larry's mouth.

Crowded, as usual. Customers wait in line outside the Union. Larry The Lung, in full costume, walks toward the Union; customers wave and smile at him, and he waves back. REMY’S POV - INSIDE THE COSTUME there’s little room to maneuver. Remy peers out through t hidden mesh eyeholes, trying to keep up the act. He walks down the line of ailing. customers --
Hey! Hey, Larry! Remy is spun around by a HEAVYSET MAN holding a coughing dog.

You think we could get a picture? The guy throws an arm around Remy, lifting the dying pooc into his face as his WIFE takes a snapshot. He sing-songs HEAVYSET MAN (CONT’D) We’re gonna get Muffin here a new widdle biddie heart, aren’t we? Yes we are! Top of the line! Yes we are! Remy extricates himself and heads for the Union doors. As usual, two GUARDS man the metal detectors. Remy does his best to wave at them -- they wave back -- h walks through -- ALARMS BLARE. Remy instinctively keeps walking -- But ARMED GUARDS swarm out of every crevice like roaches with the lights turned off. Customers start to shout -- Remy spins -- more guards -- Turns back to run out -- even more -- he’s trapped --
But the guards and alarm aren’t for him. They're . surrounding a FREAKED-OUT MAN in a white shirt, his voice high, crazed.

Is this the return line? Somebody tell me, where’s the return line? The guards tighten the circle. FREAKED-OUT MAN (CONT’D) I’m here to -- I missed a few payments, but -- but I thought rather than make you guys come out -- Raising his scanner, the lead guard PINGS the customer.
(into radio) We've got an eight month past due pancreas out here. The man unbuttons his shirt.
I didn’t want to make it difficult. I know how hard it is, trying to keep a profit margin -- ‘cause you have to pay the -- the Repo Men --
Sir, just calm down and you can come inside, talk to a credit supervisor. But the guy’s too far gone to talk anything out.

So I thought maybe -- maybe if I did it for you -- you’d gimme a break -- He takes off his pants, tossing them on the mall floor, a in the process, he’s pulled out a 9-inch KNIFE -- The guards raise their rifles -- the crowd cowers -- the man raises the knife high -- And STABS it into his own stomach. Everyone stops, transfixed, as he pulls the knife back an forth, committing fully to this odd hari-kari -- Then, raising his free arm high, like a salute -- He PLUNGES his hand into the wound. Grunting softly, his expression barely changing, he tugs at something. Hard. He stumbles forward -- a new scream from the crowd -- and then backwards, still tugging, still searching --

And with his final ounce of strength, he yanks mightily - Ripping out his artificial pancreas. He holds it in the air, the cords and tissue and blood dripping to the floor And then collapses in a heap outside the Credit Union doors. Chaos ensues.
start SHOOTING the dead man’s body -- customers screaming As Frank angrily rushes into the mall. He glances at the carnage and picks up the pancreas.
Who reclaimed this organ? Who reclaimed this goddamned organ???
The customer, sir. He did it himself.
Credit Union clients do not reclaim their own organs.
Yes, sir. This one did, sir. Frank stands in the doorway, looking at the bloody mess. Shaking his head. Disgusted.
Customers. Don’t know their goddamned place anymore. We MOVE with a pissed-off Frank back into:
As all the worried CLIENTS file out of the sales cubicles trying to figure out what the commotion was.
Nothing to worry about, folks. Just a little misunderstanding. Free coffee in the cubicles. Frank pushes past the crowd, moving into:
Walking to his desk -- still steaming -- When the door SLAMS behind him. He turns -- And is suddenly on his knees, forced into a headlock. He looks up --  70.
stands over him, his bottom half still dressed in the Lar the Lung costume.
Afternoon, boss. With a single move, Remy flings Frank into his office chair. Remy pulls a pistol on him with his left hand -- And with his right, he slaps
bearing Ray’s Union tattoo, onto the desk. Still bloody.

That’s what’1ll happen to the next one you send. And the one after that. I can guarantee you'll run out of Repo Men before I run out of ways to kill them. Frank stares at Remy. At the gun pointed in his face.
Can I say something?
It’s your office.
How long before you slip up?
That's the $800,000 question. Give or take.
And the girl?
You come after her, you come after me. Frank nods -- he understands.
Shoulda taken the job as the lung. You look good in that costume.
Itches like a motherfucker.
Yeah, that’s what the kid says, too. (beat) (MORE)

I don’t suppose you’1l wanna stick around for an exit interview? Remy smiles a bit at that -- shakes his head -- Then TASERS Frank into unconsciousness. Remy hauls the top half of the Larry the Lung costume bac on. Time to head back out.
Remy, out of costume now but still flush with adrenaline, bounds up the stairs, a bag under his arm --
And into the hotel room. Beth sits at the far end of the room, an odd, strained look on her face.

Your knight in bulletproof armor just bought us some more time. Plus, stopped at the store and lifted some of those artichoke hearts you wanted - But Beth’s expression doesn’t change. She looks... scared
What?
Your ex-wife’s quite the hostess. Served me coffee and everything. Remy freezes. He knows that voice.
sits behind him, at the other end of the room. The jig is pretty much officially up.
That’s the thing with me and Jake: Somehow, no matter where we were, he always ended up right behind me.
A DRILL SERGEANT leads a younger Remy, Jake, and a gang o eager soldiers down a long hallway.
You tank boys will be training inside this hangar. (MORE)

It is where you will eat, where you will shit, and where you will sleep, because once you’re in the desert, that tank will be your home. You will only be allowed outside into the real world once you have proven that you will not fuck it up. They come to a stop inside a hangar, where tanks sit side by-side, evenly spaced. The drill sergeant hands out numbers. Remy gets number 2; Jake has number 8.

DRILL SERGEANT (CONT’D) You will be assigned to tanks based on number, because your names no longer matter. In the heat of battle, I do not want your meager minds taxed by the difficulty of remembering your names. He looks down at his clipboard:
Number one and number five, take your tank. Don’t touch anything. The two soldiers salute and run toward a tank, scrambling up top to drop down inside. He walks along, assigning mor

Numbers four and ten, take your tank. Don’t touch anything. Six and nine, take your tank. Don’t touch anything. Two and eight, take your tank -- Remy and Jake start to run -- BOOM -- an explosion behind them -- SOLDIER #5 is launched upwards out of his tank at 100MPH SLAMMING into the ceiling of the hangar -- And falling, THUDDING to the ground at Remy’s feet, still strapped into an ejection seat. He’s quite dead. A moment later, his parachute opens near the top of the hangar and flutters down next to his body. The sergeant takes one look at the body on the floor.
Don't - touch - anything.

Remy sits in a control chair -- like the one in the concussion test -- at the front of this high-tech tank, twisting and turning as he tries to get comfy.  73. Jake sits behind him in the gunner’s chair.
Me in front, Jake right behind. That’s how it always worked.
Carol never served me coffee. Jake’s got his taser out, but he’s not pointing it at anyone. Yet. Remy couldn’t make a move if he wanted to. A though their conversation is casual, it’s strained. Tense
Beth does a lot of things Carol doesn’t do. (beat) I was just at the office. Musta missed you.
Actually, I’m on a new assignment.
Oh yeah? Who’s the client?
Just some asshole I spent half my life with. Here’s the thing, though: I got this smokin’ chick coming over tonight.
No shit.
And she’s easy --
Just your type.
I'd hate to leave her waiting for me. Maybe it’d be better if I didn’t start hunting this guy down til tomorrow morning. : Remy’s eyes narrow -- is Jake giving him an out?
Sure. Get a good night’s sleep.  74.
Only... the thing that worries me is what happens if this fucker finds a way out of the country before nine A.M. tomorrow? You know I’m a 48 states kinda guy. I don’t do South America.
Then I guess... he’d be clear?
I guess so. If he could get out.
Which he couldn’t.
No. Never happen. Jake stands, brushes off his pants. Goes to the door.
Hey -- Jake turns. Remy starts to speak, then stops. Instead of whatever he was going to say, he just says: REMY (CONT’D) See you later.
Try not to. And Jake’s out the door.

Long lines snake around the airport terminal as PASSENGER wait to pass through metal and weapons detectors -- As well as walk-through artiforg scanners. A bored-lookin REPO MAN sits next to one of them. He waves a BUSINESSMAN to walk through -- A green wave of light washes over the businessman's body As an ARTIFICIAL LIVER appears inside his body, as if glowing from within. It’s just a projection, a hologram- type image placed onto his frame, but it clearly shows hi artiforg. A PING sounds out, and a bulb above him turns green. He walks through. The Repo Man waves the next passenger in, and we MOVE BAC through the line to find Remy and Beth, waiting their tur Blood from Beth’s knee wound still seeps through a bandag
So he’s just letting us go?
Jake doesn’t let anybody go. He’s giving us a head start, that’s all. What we do with it is up to us.
But nobody ever gets through the airport. I don’t like this.

I’m not in love with it, either. Just try and hide that limp. Remy checks the area, then swiftly walks to the front of the line, lifting his sleeve so the passengers see his tattoo. They don’t come near him. He approaches the bored Repo Man -- who perks up, eyes opening wide -- he recognizes Remy -- Remy grabs him and pulls him to the side, speaking quickl REMY (CONT’D) Look -- I know you know what’s going on, and I know what kind of commission’s in it for you. What I don't know is how many other Union guys you've got in shouting distance, but I’d lay short odds they’11 get here long after my scalpel’s stuck in your throat. (beat) Now: Will you help me?
Yeah. Christ, man, of course, for you

Good choice. See the little lady in line? She’s with me. When we go through, all you have to do is shut down the scanner. Once we're past, power it back up again. Two seconds, tops. Got it? The Repo Man nods. Remy’s back to all smiles as he steps line next to Beth.
. REMY (CONT’D) It’s taken care of.
What do I do?
Just walk.  76. Indeed, when they get to the walk-through scanner
flicks a switch.
hustle on through and
flicks the system back on. Just that fast. The lights are back on, more passengers are streaming through, and all seems just like it was before. Remy and Beth walk away, down toward the gates.
That was easy. Let’s do it again! She playfully turns around, and Remy grabs her waist and spins her back. No time for games yet.
Remy and Beth sit on uncomfortable plastic chairs, waitin for their flight to board. The gate sign reads SAO PAOLO, BOARDING 8:35. Remy, tense, checks his watch -- REMY‘S WATCH reads 8:30
What do we do once we get there?
We'll talk about it in the air.
But --
In the air. Remy scans the crowd -- passengers going by, everything seems normal -- But something's odd. He stands, looks around -- Out of the corner of his eye, he notices
burning down a stairway, heading for their terminal.
Remy grabs Beth, running behind the gate counter. The GAT ATTENDANT looks down --
Excuse me, this is for airport per -- Remy TASERS the guy, and he falls, hard. He turns to Beth -- and grabs her knee. She winces --
What the hell are you doing?

I’m sorry. This is going to hurt. A lot. Before she can respond, Remy braces her leg with his knee locking her in place -- And whips out a scalpel, going for her knee. We move away As Beth clamps her lips tight, suppressing a scream. Remy working as fast as he can. Just as he said, he’s an exper Seconds later, he holds up her overdue artiforg kneecap.
Wait here. It’s not as if Beth has a choice -- she’s passed out. Remy pops up from behind the counter and practically jogs up. to the:
who looks back and forth -- from Remy to the approaching Repo Men hustling down to the terminal. He’s petrified --
C’mon, man, it’s what you would have done --

You're right. With incredible force, Remy JABS an edge of the artificia kneecap between the Repo Man’s shoulder blades. He grunts As Remy steps away, up to the approaching Union Men, and points out the Repo Man, frantically batting at his back. REMY (CONT’D) There he is. Easy commission. The three Union Men, acting on impulse, PING the Airport Repo Man --
all come back the same: DURA-JOINT KNEECAP REPLACEMENT --
Wait -- I’m not -- Their tasers fly, and passengers SCREAM. Chaos erupts in the terminal. Remy collects Beth, throws her over his shoulder, and disappears into the frightened crowd...
Hiding behind a dumpster. Remy watches over Beth, who's beginning to wake, slowly. She’s got a tourniquet around her leg, but it’s ugly.
Did we... make it?
Yeah. We made it. Welcome to South America. Beth’s eyes flutter open. She sees the alley. They close again in defeat.
Fuck you.
You need a new kneecap.
Great. Let's go down to the Credit Union. Maybe we’1ll get a discount if they kill us both at the same time. Remy lets out a heavy sigh -- there’s no good plan.
I know somebody who can help.
We can’t trust anyone. There’s a reward out --
Asbury’s clean. He’s outside the Union. Remy stops short -- anger, almost anguish on his face.
Jesus, Beth, you wanna go to an 2? Lemme tell you something about those vermin:
Remy kneels over an unconscious host. He plucks the liver clean, boxes it, then leaves a yellow receipt on the body He leaves the apartment, shutting the lights off behind him.

Those sleazy motherfuckers took food off my table for years. Black market, aftermarket, whatever you wanna call it, they’re vultures, plain and simple. After several beats of darkness, the door reopens and a flashlight pierces the darkness. A rail thin, beady eyed OUTSIDER sleazoid slinks into the house. Approaches the fallen body, then sets to work, flashlight in mouth, plucking out the remaining artiforgs, tossing them in a sack.
A Union man takes what’s overdue. Outsiders scavenge the rest.
Remy backs away from Beth. He’s making a stand.
Outsiders are the plague. I’m not going. No fuckin’ way.
So you’re gonna... what? Knit me a kneecap? Standoff.
A cab pulls to the curb and Remy pulls Beth out, hoisting her over his shoulder.
Beth, leaning heavily on Remy, knocks on The Outsider’s door. No answer. Remy pounds hard on the door -- nothing. Beth presses against the low ceiling.
He used to leave me a key up here...

How well do you know this asshole? Beth just smiles. Remy’s eyes narrow. RUMBLE. Down the hall. It’s a freight elevator. We hear a DING -- the SHOOSH of doors opening -- then a CREAK, CREA Remy tenses, pulling his gun -- edging in front of Beth - A leg slides into view -- only it’s horizontal and three feet off the ground. beneath their pictures: PAID IN FULL.
what -- that easy?

who convulses and drops to the ground.
